By Art Jahnke, CIO.com MacCentral Like just about everyone else, Francis Uy has no use for spam. In fact, Uy hates spam. He hates it because it fills up his inbox with a lot of offensive junk, and he hates it because of the hassle that it brings to one of the most helpful technologies that has appeared in his lifetime, the Internet. "Anyone who uses the Internet for business knows how much time and bandwidth it takes to deal with all of that junk," said Uy. But unlike just about everyone else, Francis Uy decided to do something about spam. After receiving an unwanted offer to buy anti-virus software, Uy, a tech specialist at Johns Hopkins University, visited the seller's website and found the name -- Allen Moore -- and address of the spammer. He then posted that information on another site, where he encouraged site visitors to use Maryland's anti-spam legislation to sue spammers. As it turned out, site visitors took a more direct action, calling Moore on the phone and signing him up as a subscriber to magazines that he never subscribed to. When the issue finally did make it to court, it was Moore who brought it there, claiming that he had received eight harassing telephone calls, more than 200 unwanted magazines and dozens of products that he never ordered. Moore sued Uy for harassment. On Monday, a Maryland district court judge ruled that Moore was wrong: Uy had not harassed him. At least, Uy hadn't harassed him any more than a newspaper harasses people whose names are published along with descriptions of their misdeeds. The website could stay, the judge said, and Moore could either take a hike or appeal.

"Don't you ever wonder maybe if you took a left turn instead of taking a right you could be somebody different?" -dave matthews What do I regret? It's hard to say. Every time I think about what might have been, it makes me look at what... is. I'm happy with what I've done so far, and even happier at what I hope is to come. I'm comfortable, energized, motivated and in a good situation. I could be better just as easy as I could be worse. . Of course I'd do some things differently now rather than then - I'd be more bold, mostly, I'd risk more - but I feel that I've made the best decisions I could given the information and situations I was in at the time. To feel otherwise is useless and counterproductive. Making any sort of rational judgement based on incomplete or inaccurate information - such as 'what might have been' - is no way to live. So do I have any regrets? No. Any ones that pop up in my mind I smash with the knowledge that they're inherently negative and irrelevant. It's a struggle.

First dream was to be a archaeologist. I still dream of that, but I now know that it doesn't mean being Indiana Jones, and that it requires as much scientific/mathematical knowledge as historical. I hence settled on being an historian. Most memorable dream is the repeating nightmare I had as a kid, whenever my bed was positioned by the bedroom window; I would dream of a hand reaching in at night and grabbing me, pulling me out. It progressed to where hands were grabbing at me from the hallway ceiling and floor, and from the streets of my neighborhood. Yikes, can't forget that. Scary dreams ... well, see above. That was my most memorable dream and only nightmare that I can vividly remember. Though I have had dreams in which I was shot by a gun, or beaten up, but those never seemed as scary for some reason. Remembering dreams ... I dream a lot, and usually remember the dreams quite well when I first wake up, but once I start going through my day, I forget them. Sometimes I forget them entirely, sometimes I only remember a *feeling* about the dream, and sometimes I just forget details. Sometimes, very very rarely, I recall vivid detail in its entirety. Lucid dreams ... I rarely realize that I am dreaming during dreams, or even if I do, I don't seem to have the ability to change them at will. I do recall having dreams in which I know I'm dreaming, and am waiting to see what's going to happen next (often I am pursuing something in the dream that I'm afraid to do in reality) but usually when that happens I wake up before I progress past that point, DAMN. I've often had dreams where I'm conscious in the dream that I need to wake up, that I'm late for something, and lo and behold, I wake up and I'm late for something. Day dreaming ... I do that a ton. Especially when I'm listening to music. I put together novels listening to music, for goodness sake. I used to day dream a lot in high school, but not anymore. Nowadays at university I really do have to pay attention, or I'll freak come test time. I day dream a lot in my bedroom, either with music or while I'm working on my artwork. I also daydream occassionally when I'm driving on nice days, and day dream a lot when I go outside into nature, or when I exercise. I'm artistically inclined-- we HAVE to daydream. The mind never rests. ;) Did I cover everything? ^__^

Tornado dreams are never scary they just always have the smae plot line: It's a beautiful and nice day and suddenly I get the urge to look up at the horizon and I see 3-7 tornadoes ominously looming a short distance away all coming towards us. I'm always with a group of people and they just don't see it. They all say then wow, we had no idea, it's a good thing that you were there to warn us. Then it end. Just like that I'll have it like once every month, every two months, for the last few years. Also the snake ones, there's a snake and I wake up and I can't move. I'm paralized and tingley with random fright. The thing is, I'm not afriad of snake, I'd be the first one to pick them up and scare my sister/friends with it. I don't get it. Remembering dreams the only time I don't remember them is if I have to wake up really fast because I'm late for work, need to be somewhere and such. I've never been in an accident because I've been day dreaming- actually it makes my trip go faster, all of a sudden I'll snap out of it and be like hey I'm approaching my driveway, hey this song is almost done, oh the movie is over. Hrm, maybe I should do a bit less of this day dreaming. Some people take it for absent mindedness- when that's exactly the opposite, I was thinking so much I was distracted by what was literally infront of me. Also clearly what ever was infront of me wasn't that interesting or else I wouldn't be day dreaming. I'm not talking about the random productive thinking like making a grocery list, what's on Dave Letterman tonight?, did I remember to water the plants? Daydreaming for me is the stuff where I'm just very much not conscience of the thinking that's occuring.

The most exhausted I've ever been... What comes immediately to mind is the time I got lost in the woods...in the snow...at twilight. I was visiting Lake Tahoe with some friends. My then girlfriend, her dog, Jeroux, and I decided to go off and spend some time alone. She had gone through a relativley stressfull day involving a speeding ticket, driving for two hours in an attempt to acquire some last minute concert tickets (in vain), and Jeroux peeing on the bed. Yeah, it's time for a quiet walk in the woods. Well, since I have this fascination with being on top of things, I decided we should try to get the top of this peak down near the southwest coast of the lake. We found a good place to park the car in a place that wasn't so much advertised as a place for just anybody to leave their car (in a neighborhood), but was nonetheless far enough out of the way as to not draw attention. Hiking up hill in snow is tough, but we had a lovely trail to follow of previous adventurers who hit the same trailhead as we. The trip up was a lot of fun and included some jumps off rocks into snowbanks and a friendly snow ball fight. (Jesus, I loved that girl and was/am a total moron for lettting her go...another story) The daylight was fading faster than we were ascending, so we made the decision to turn back before making it to the top. Where exactly we left the trail for the first time and why is still somewhat of a mystery to me. I remember running downhill for a bit and having fun "falling" and rolling in the snow. This was obviously something better done off the trail and in the unpacked snow off to the sides. Ok, so we left the trail to frolick. When we first crossed OVER the trail is definitely still a mystery. I sure as hell didn't know then, because when I became aware of the fact that we needed to find the trail to make it back to the car I was convinced that direction I would lead us in for the next hour and a half was the correct way. It was after entering woods that were wholly unfamiliar and spending a great deal of time crawling through brush, and trying to wade through powder snow up to my waist, that my error in judgement became excruciatingly clear. If this had happened when the daylight wan't fading into night I might have turned around and backtracked uphill and got us on the path, but that wasn't the case, and that isn't what we did. By the way, this whole trial was made worse by the fact that THE WHOLE TIME Colleen (the girlfriend) had been lobbying to go the other (which turned out to be the right) direction. We just headed down. Down towards the lake which would eventually put us on the road which we could follow to the car. The dog's paws started to bleed. We were occaisionally crossing stream beds that were hidden by the snow and sucked us down. It was long, it was arduous, but the sight of the road was like a rebirth...I have never, ever been so happy to see a road. Then we had quite a nice walk just to get to the entrance of the neighborhood where we had left the car. Then the horror truly began...we had to walk UPHILL to get to the car. We had to meander through this maze of roads without the aid of light to gaive us our land marks. Yup, we managed to take a couple of wrong turns (which we decided on together, thank you very much). When we finally made it to the car, I was so sore, so tired, so exhausted, I could barely walk. I was never so happy to see a car. Ask Colleen, I had been telling her for the twenty minutes before that moment that I didn't think I could walk anymore. But she was right, I did it for another twenty minutes. She was the strong one for us that night. I think it helped that she was a marathoner. (Is that a word???) Getting back to the chalet where our friends were sorta wondering where we were was a quiet car ride. There was a brief snarl I indulged myself at the bitch friend of a friend who just had to mock people in pain and then I headed off to take a long, hot shower. Our friend Pam happened to have some Vicodin and offered me one. I was never so happy to see a Vicodin. I then slept like a baby for a solid ten hours in the bed that I had never been so happy to see.

Most exausted was my senior year of high school, despite my parents very strict rule and my beyond busy schedules I would routeinly go to bed at sometime like 1am and then ben up by 6am to get ready for school and whatnot. So a usual day would be, get up, the whole breakfast deal, drive to school, fall asleep in at least one of my classes, go to work at the bank, go to play rehersal, and then go out for dinner with the older cast at the local Big Boy and close the place down, then crash when I got home. I never had homework so things worked out ok for me. That is until Easter weekend in 2000. I convinced my parents to let me drive to Adrian MI to see some friends in Jesus Christ SuperStar at the Croswell Opera House. Saturday night I hadn't slept much at all, and after the show we they had a cast party. Well about 4am the party finally breaks up, I drive following my friends back to his place. I faught to stay awake, I had the music blaring, I was singing at the top of my lungs, I drank a juice box for some sugar, I had the windows down it was freezing, but to no avail. I was like 10 mins from the final destination, and I had just turn the corner in the farmland area just south of Ypsilanti and gone maybe about 100 feet after turning the corner and I hear a noise. It sounds like gravel, I wake up and try to swerve but I watch as if in slow motion the sign hit my car, snap in half, break the windshield and disappear and then feel this huge bump as the little foot bridge keeps me on the road. The sign had been a creek warning sign, and that little foot bridge kept me from driving off into the ravine where a man eating tree could have gotten me. I somehow have enough wits to flash my lights and the guy comes around and says to turn off my car. The other half of the sign had spliced the underneith part of my car and fluids or all colors and textures were streaming down the hill. I then went into shock and don't remember much, I took all the stuff from my car and then left the car there and then going to sleep at my friend's house. Yeah not a happy story, I will never drive tired again that's for sure. I now try to get more sleep, things could have been very serious had I gone off the road and into the ravine, not to mention the car was totalled I had to buy one now. Luckily I had been able to save $5,000 in my "Going to Europe Fund" but I needed a car and so there went that dream.

Survive is such a specific word, as I don't think anyone's life is dependent or exclusively bound to the "internet", so much so, that depriving one of it would result in death. But since I don't think the literal sense was implied, I will verbally gesticulate on the notion/question of "could you get by as well without the internet?" I do think I would get by, in fact I would probably be better off. Let say that there was no such thing as the internet (as opposed to it existing and just not having it) I'm sure I would have filled my days with more reading, more writing and maybe even more travel. Friends that I keep contact with via email, I may have just jumped in the car and gone and visited them (which is what I did do on a few occasions before the internet really got big) if I didn't have that email connection. Since my first experience with the internet (I feel that when trying to be sardonic and trying to date yourself at the same time, one should call every thing "the" as in, The Internet, The Nintendo, The Rock 'n Roll...), and even today, I marvel at the generations of the future that will have this technology laid out before them. The internet is the first really significant invention/technology that I was around and "functioning" before it was common place. In fact, I can hear myself say "back when I was in school, we didn't have the internet" and the like. I find it remarkable that when my grandpa was a child, most of our modern day technologies didn't exist. It makes me wonder what the hell they are going to come up with between now and when I am grandpa age. I do, however, think that many of the generations to come will become more and more dependent on the internet, and would suffer greatly without it. Not only is it a sole means of communication for some of the inept youth of today, it is the focal point of informational reference. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but a dependency on it could be. Would one have any idea what "the Midas Touch" really meant without copying it to Yahoo and trying to find out that way? I'm reminded of a series of books where the evolution of the net is fully developed to the point where people have implants to access remote networks that can be viewed internally, in the mind's eye. Their dependency on it was so severe, that when it fell, there were nations of illiterate people, unable to write, or properly function in society. Personally I can see how the internet has made my life more convienent in most regards, and in that sense I guess I appriciate it for what it's worth. I think it's a very good question, though. It makes one look at an internet they may take for granted, and perhaps even enable one to appriciate it(or fear it) Normally this appriciation is only accomplished when that something is lost, which for the sake of itwillfail, the Captain, blogs, and everything else, I hope does not happen any time soon. That's all for now

on regrets one thing I regret, that one little moment in time, a flash, a few words and then boom, there it is- regret, was during my seventh grade year, playing basketball against one of our school rivals. We were going back and forth,(both in the literal sense that we were going back and forth over the court, and in the figurative sense as the score was going back and forth between who was winning) but there isn't enough drama for me to play this out, really. Anyway I was really trying to get some rebounds and I kept pushing against this defender. A natural move, and a semilegal one at that. He was so perturbed, so upset that I kept moving him out of the way, that he did some sort of cry baby face and yelled 'quit pushing'. Now, I'll admit this next part with shame...at some point later in the game, shortly thereafter, I actually said "sorry about pushing you". What the fuck? I regret it because I did stop pushing him, and subsequently didn't do as well as I could have. Years later when I was playing at a higher level I found out how much better I was at 'getting into position" (which is slang for pushing), and realized that my sense to have everything balanced overcame my sense to do well, and I let some cry baby little fuck change the way I did something, I really regret not stepping up and not pushing...the defender, and myself.

On trips I heard my uncle's voice shouting to me. I heard something in his voice, something that was serious, something fearful in an otherwise fearless man. He told me something happened to Grandpa...maybe he said heart attack, maybe I just knew. Something instinctive inside triggered, my heart suddenly beat faster and an overwhelming sense of worry struck me the moment he shouted. We're going to the hospital, he said. My eyes and my heart kept asking "what's going on?". I was old enough to know, but the fear, the oncoming sense of loss, propelled me into something almost childlike. Had to be strong, like him, like Grandpa. Had to show Grandma that everything would be okay, the foundation was strong. Had to show Mom that there was no reason to worry any more than the situation called for, had to be strong. I don't remember the trip to the hospital, other than thinking that. The doctor said 'he's gone....come in...say good-bye..." Tears pushed on my eyes so much they hurt, had to be strong...show my uncles that I was tough like them...we walked into the room, where he lay....defeated...my grandma wails out 'what am I going to do now?' as she clutches his hand. We whisper good bye, my vision blurry, tears soak my face...my breath shortens up....everyone whispers good bye. They had to pull my Grandma back. If I only make one of those trips in my life, that will be fine with me, though I somehow suspect it won't be...such is life, such is death.

D****** still tells people I threw her out of a 5th floor window. One time M*** got really mad because we walked for what seemed like ages to reach a brick structure he wanted to sit inside of and as we got within feet of it a sprinker went off and squirted right where he wanted to sit. Ah yes, thinking in bed. For me it's a three step process. First, I get into bed and lie on my back and and think about what I need to do/get done tomorrow, in the next fews days, make mental lists, etc. Quite often I'll remember oh shit, I had to do an exam for my online Environmental Law and Policy class by midnight- so then there's me doing it in 5 mins, (sometimes that's all it takes). I'll go to bed then, and then remember I forgot to shut the sound off of my computer. Then go back to bed, then remember the streetlight that shines through the bathroom window and shut the door that connects it to my bedroom. I'll remember to set my cell phone/alarm clock for the appropriate time depending on which day of the week it is. Eventually, I'll run out of things to remember or just get bored and I'll move on to the next step. Step two, I turn and lay on my side and review my day. Usually just smile, remember little moments and silly remarks that caught my attention, think about the really great people in my life, maybe say a little prayer- give thanks, things like that. By this time I'm tired, I don't even bother going to bed unless I am tired or I never leave step one. I eventually will feel everything is accomplished then and only then I turn over once again and finally go to sleep on my stomach. The first thing I think about when I wake up? Lately I'll wake up and smile and think about the things I had thought about during step two just before I went to bed. Otherwise, it depends on the day actually. It's either ok- gotta get ready for work now no time for the snooze, or hit the snooze about 2 time and go to class. On the weekends, usually I can breathe. On days I'm not in a rush I will without fail remember my dreams and quite often write them down or tell the first person I see in the morning about it. Usually my friends will humor me, and listen, but I know they're not nearly as awake as I am, or they're getting really good at the smile and nod thing. I think the most important part of that interaction is just hearing myself out loud so I can reflect on it, make an attempt to interpret it and so forth.

"Pat, if it's true that what goes up, must come down... then does that mean that the sky is falling?" It's all relative, so it depends. Another "it depends" answer, I love it. The sky itself might not be falling but you could be, if you were in orbit. You would be falling around the earth. That's why you are weightless, because you are falling. The spaceship is falling but doesn't crash into Earth because it is moving fast enough horizontally to fall around the earth, because Earth is round. Weird, isn't it. Anyway. The sky while not actually falling is moving. The Earth moves around the Sun, The Sun moves around the center of our galaxy and our galaxy is also moving. It's more like we are falling into the sky than the sky is falling into us. Yes it's very trippy. And what goes up does come down, unless it's velocity exceeds the escape velocity of Earth's gravitational field. This speed is about 11,100 meters/second or approximately 25,000 MPH (this does not include air resistance which is a factor). If it's going that fast, then it will not come down. The object will leave the planet. Neat huh?

Mike (Murphy), Well I had a nice reply to this, then I switched pages in my browser and it blew it away, so here's the take from an article on mlb.com The Infield Fly Rule was instituted to protect the offense from a possibly "unfair" double play. If there were runners on first and second (or bases loaded) and less than 2 out, runners would normally hold their base on a pop-up to the infield since the ball would, in all likelihood, be caught. Without the Infield Fly Rule, an infielder could drop an easy pop-up (or let it drop untouched) and turn a double play, since the runners would then be forced. The rules makers didn't think this was fair and instituted this rule. The Infield Fly Rule is only in effect when runners are on first and second (or bases loaded) and less than 2 out. It states that the batter is automatically out if he hits a fly ball "which can be caught by an infielder with ordinary effort." The umpires loudly announce and signal, "Infield Fly, batter is out!" so that the runners are alerted that, even if the ball is dropped, they do not have to leave their bases.

No problem Dan, this one is easy. If you asked some people they would say that the 4th dimension is time. Our world is in three physical dimensions and then it moves through time so that's the 4th dimension. This is an ok answer I guess, but slightly incorrect. There are at least 4 physical dimensions. Einstein (of course) proved it. But more on that later. We can't directly see into the 4th dimension because we only exist in 3D. What would the 4th dimension look like? Carl Sagan had this thought experiment in one of his books (Cosmos, if I remember correctly). Picture a 1-D world, It would just be a line. 1-D creatures could only exist and move back and forth on this line. Then take the line and add a line at a right angle (90 degrees) to the first line. Now you can move back and forth, up and down, but only in a 2D plane (picture a square). This is the traditional X-Y axis if any of you remember geometry. 2D creatures could be any shape, squares, triangles, whatever - but they only exist on a single plane. Now make another right angle to each direction on the plane. Instead of a square shaped plane now you have a cube. This is the world we live in. Objects can be of any shape, they have length, width and height. Now this is the hard part, which we can't really understand because we don't live in 4-D. Take a cube and make a right angle to each direction on the cube. That is what the 4th dimension would look like. But like I said we can't grasp the concept. Anyway, back to Einstein. This is how he proved that the 4th physical dimension exists. I forget when they did this experiment but I can look it up if anyone is interested. Einstein predicted this: He said that during a solar eclipse that was upcoming that we would be able to see a star that was behind the sun at the time. Based on the position of the Earth, the Sun and this particular star we should not be able to see it because at the time it would be on the other side of the sun from us. (Remember, the earth rotates around the sun so we knew the star's location already because at other times of the year the star would not be behind the sun) During the eclipse obviously the sun's light is diminshed greatly. And on the edge of the sun, where normally the sun's intense light would make it impossible to see, the scientists did in fact see this star, which should have been BEHIND the sun. But it was not! What was going on here? The 4th Dimension! The light from the star curved around the sun due to the fact that space is in (at least) 4 dimensions. Matter is what causes space to be curved and the Sun is the most massive object in our solar system so it causes space to "curve" more. Ok, now I have to get back to work. Send in more questions! They can be about anything. I'll answer them all.

Pat, they say when you are spinning out of control on snow / ice you should turn the opposite way of how you want to react. Is this for front and rear wheel drive cars? Listen to your father. Usually when your car starts to slide it is the back tires that will slide out. To counteract this and to get the car pointed straight again you turn the wheel in the direction that the back end of the car swung out. Let's say you are turning left in your example or rounding a corner to the left. The back of the car goes to your right, so you want to cut the wheel back to the right to straighten the car out. Here's the basic physics: Centripetal forces act on the car when you change direction (like turning around a curve). This force is outward from the curve, it would tend to push the car off the road to the outside of the curve. Normally the tires do a good job of gripping the road via frictional forces. But when you hit a slippery part the tires lose friction and the centripetal force takes over and the car slides to the outside of the curve. Now if all four wheels lose friction with the road... Well, you are pretty much in trouble at this point until the front tires get some grip back. In that situation you should turn the wheel in the direction that you want the car to go in, and apply some power. This happened to me actually. On freeway, it was wet. Cut wheel to avoid car in front of me who slammed on brakes. Cut wheel back sharply and overcorrected, send myself into a skid sideways on the freeway. Front of car was facing toward the far left lane, so I cut the wheel to the right so I was pointed back in the right direction.

The state of the economy as it relates to the unemployment factor...a lofty goal, let's see what we can do. First off, job security, in today's business environment, is an illusion. Regardless of what industry you work for, how long you've been there, and whether you're considered a "just cause" or "at will" employee, you can and possibly may lose your job at a moment's notice. A law may have created your job, but, the next administration could just as easily un-create it. I work for a University, which normally would leave me with no question as to my future employment status. Two people in our department just got laid-off because their division wasn't bringing in enough money. The biggest problem people in Detroit are facing (and Dan can back me up here), is that the entire economy of southeastern Michigan is inextricably linked to the automotive industry. When the economic downturn started, the Big Three made fewer ads (advertising and marketing are also huge), bought less ad time (Detroit is the 9th largest television market in the country), sold fewer cars (nationwide), made fewer cars, laid off workers, and closed a couple factories. To actually attempt to detail the butterfly effect of that is mind-boggling, but it's not hard to imagine the effect it had on the banks, gas stations, grocery stores, restaurants, movie theatres, bars, pool halls and shopping malls. The saving grace of the auto industry was the morning of the 11th of September. When all this unwashed patriotic brouhaha was first being whipped up by El Presidente, and particularly the part about everybody doing their part, going back to "life as normal," and maintaining the economy, the auto industry kicked in the the 0% financing campaign. This got people buying cars again (we bought a Focus, mid-October), which is great, but the car companies were losing their asses on it, which, as you might suspect, isn't so good.

RE: Suicide I've never really been able to get a firm handle on that, myself. I have friends who have had to suffer the consequences of having a friend or relative die at their own hands, and basically, that's something from which you never recover. I know someone who attempted to take his life and through some circumstance or other did not. Just going back to think about that makes me shudder. It may seem a bit selfish, and again insensitive, but I can't even begin to imagine the number of ways my life would have been affected had my friend killed himself. Even though I haven't talked to him in probably at least six years, not many days go by when I don't think, at least briefly, about him being one of my first friends in school after we moved to Livonia. Our plan to create a comic book, Street Urchins . Him being the person that introduced me to the Martial Arts movie genre. Him being the person that got me interested in playing the keyboard. Him being the person that introduced me to the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit issue. Him being the person that made me see how wrong I was, not the first, but undoubtedly the last time I ever uttered a racist slur in anger. Him being the person that had more impact on my current musical landscape than anyone else, because it was at his house that I heard for the first time ever Depeche Mode, Nirvana, the Sisters of Mercy, Bob Marley and Skinny Puppy, just to name a few. Him being the person that introduced me to BBSing and consequently many of the people I now consider life-long friends, up to and including my wife. So, no, I can't even begin to imagine the number of ways my life would have been affected had my friend killed himself. Because my life, as I know it, would not exist. Dennis, wherever you are now, thank you. I owe you my life.

Okay, so I'm the only one who wants to use this space for long-winded, debate-inducing diatribes. I'll deal with it. As I was tooling around the net, my attention was drawn to a urlLink column in the Boston Globe about the "blog phemonenon." Personally, I thought it was an ill-conceived hack-job, and told the author as much. Here's my e-mail to him: To: urlLink beam@globe.com Subject: talk is cheap, indeed.... Alex "Esteemed Journalist at a Widely Distributed Corporate-Owned Newspaper" Beam - As I'm sure you've heard by now, more than you ever possibly thought when you started writing that piece, your remarks on the "blogging" fad are a little off-base. "Welcome to Blogistan, the Internet-based journalistic medium where no thought goes unpublished ..." This is your first mistake, really...most web-loggers don't try to convince themselves, or their readers that they are journalists, or are subject to the supposedly high standards of "journalistic integrity." They are, if thinking about it in old-media terms will help you, stream-of-consciousness op-ed writers. Which is actually kind of funny, considering how many stream-of-consciousness op-ed writers "in medi(a) that people actually read" try to convince folks that they're journalists... Secondly, if John Ellis' whole purpose in updating his blog is to please the 35 people who are "really into" his updated golf scores, so be it. Web-loggers are neither attempting to meet the general public interest, nor are they catering to the lowest common denominator. Because our solvency is not dependent on being able to sell enough advertising to off-set the costs of operation. Web-loggers take the notion of narrow-casting and run with it. Old-media icons (television programmers and the cable industry, in particular) have been trying to make that idea sell for years. Not to mention that Lileks' blog is probably the least-travelled portion of its site, because he is far more widely known around the net for his collection of pop-culture iconography. Thirdly, Andrew Sullivan, and John Ellis and James Lileks have old-media backgrounds. Their puffing up over their personal blogs is something they brought with them. I am fully aware that from an organizational standpoint it is standard operating procedure in the commercial news biz to pretend as if your past employment and body of work don't exist when you move to a new organization, or in this case, medium. You mock bloggers because it is in your best interest to do so. Much like The Globe mocks the rival newspapers, and perhaps even the broadcast news operations in your market. It's in your blood, as someone tied to (or tied down by) an "old-media" organization. The Boston Globe's survival, and consequently, your livelihood, pretty much necessitate it. If tomorrow you started working for The Boston Herald, it would be the Globe (and bloggers) that you were mocking. That's kind of the beauty of the web-logging phenomenon, and the self-congratulatory, self-referential nature of web-loggers. There is no organization to which they owe allegience, except themselves. No one is going to fire urlLink Tom Tomorrow when he makes reference to the work of Ted Rall in his blog. Nor, for that matter, are the indy.alt.rags which publish his comic likely to drop him for making reference to your article "in a medium that people actually read." Web-loggers are in a community, not a competition. Anyway, you are correct in saying that many blogs and bloggers are inane. More than a few people say the same thing about newspapers and newspaper columnists. And trust me, we are defnitely mocking you, even if there's no one to read it but ourselves. peace, Mark Geralds [UPDATE] There has been a huge backlash from the web-log community about this. Two of whom happen to be people that the writer sent letters to, soliciting their input. urlLink James Lileks - urlLink www.lileks.com (a fascinating place to go if you have any appreciation for Pop Culture or "Americana") urlLink Virginia Postrel - urlLink www.dynamist.com (today was the first day I ever heard of her or her work)

Here's a quick one, since I'm not sure what the e-mail will be like in D.C.... Our day in New York had a decidedly slow start, but interesting things happened after that. We left Dave's apartment in Queens and hit mid-town NYC in the afternoon. The information overload of Times Square threw me for a loop. Jason Bryce and I saw the new Toys R Us, a three-story toy store that makes FAO Schwartz look like a Kay-Bee Toy Store. There's a three-story indoor ferris wheel, a really big and kinda scary anamatronic T-Rex, an empire state building made of Legos (with King Kong) and enough blinking, beeping and flashing to drive just about anybody to convulsions. We wandered uptown, then took a train downtown and saw the city from the top of the Empire State building. I hadn't done that in years, and it's a cool thing to do every once in a while. It was a hazy day, though, so the limitations of our view were at just about the waterline of the island. It gave the place a "Mists of Avalon" sort of feel that was cool, but it also didn't give off the full effect of such a cool sight to see. There's a lot of street people in New York, and some of them do some crazy, impressive things to ask for your money - or maybe they just do them because they themselves are crazy. Ask me sometime about the guy who told an entire subway car that he was the Queen of England. Yesterday, we saw a guy walking around with a picture frame over his neck, telling people that - yeah - he was 'framed.' Hilarious. Today I saw something truly impressive. A woman - I think, though Jason thinks he was a man - so - a person, a blind street person (there we go) walked up and down a rough subway car, in motion, tapping his/her cane on the ground in a complicated rhythm while singing an enthusiastic motown medley, all without losing his/her balance, and while holding out a cup to take tips. Then, when the ride stopped, he/she gave the entire car some important (and probably accurate) directions about subway route changes due to the holiday weekend. The more I think about it, the more impressed I am with that performance. Wow. Later, we stopped by the hotel Roger Smith, where our friend Geoff Renaud was having a small get-together on an outdoor patio. Geoff is a Rochester-area guy (and former WXOU DJ) who now manages rock tours for a living - yes, that is just about as cool as it sounds. Check out his treats at urlLink www.geoffrenaud.com . If there's a guy out there who inspires my own wacky travel, it's him. We had dinner down in little italy, a place where there are so many restuarants so close together that they're all good by the nature of competition. I have so many carbohyrdrates in me after that amazing meal than I can live for a week off of milk and cheese. We searched around for a bar, and found that many of them were closed because of the holiday. All we could find were cheesy places (okay, one cheesy place), so we packed it in. On the way back, Dave wanted to check if the subway train went where we needed it to go. The E Train was what we were thinking of taking, but it's usually an express train during the day - which means it won't stop where we want it to. At night, during the week, it becomes a local train and does stop where we want it to. Dave was trying to see if the train had turned into a local train tonight. It was 1am, and he walked up to a fare booth attendant who was seemingly asleep. The guy wakes up slightly, and this is their conversation: Dave: Does the E train go to Queens right now, local? Guy: It runs normal. Dave: So it's an express train still. Guy. It runs normal. Dave: Because during the week it's a local train at night. Guy: Normal. Dave: So is it a local train now? Guy: It's a local train late night. Dave: Is it late night now? Guy: Yes. Dave: So it's a local train? Guy: It runs normal. Uh-huh. At the next booth, Dave asked "Is the E Train local right now?" The attendant nodded. Goes to show. That's it for today. I'm turning in, slightly. I've got about three hours to sleep before Jason and I have to bust out to take an absolutely sickening 7am bus ride to washington dc. I think it'll be my first big non-charter bus ride. I hope everything turns out well. Talk to you all soon. Somebody call me during the hockey game tomorrow and tell me how the wings are doing. Murph.

From Murph in NYC: It's New York, it's 3:30 in the morning, my head's achy, my feet stink, and I'm dog tired. The last two days have been pretty eventful - Me and my hetero-life partner Jason Bryce spent yesterday in Philadelphia, and today in New York with our friends, Brandon Oblinger and Dave Havasi. Some highlights: -We spent a night at Jason Hammonds's place in Philadelphia. The younger of his two cats is only 8 weeks old, but is already self-aware enough to identify its mortal enemy: my feet, whic he repeatedly stalked and attacked. I woke up at 4am with a Kitten wrapped around my big toe, locked in a desperate struggle for survival. I said "What the hell are you doing?" out loud - but he didn't care. I had to launch him across the room and give up a sock to distract him. -In Philadelphia, the Jasons and I were hanging out in the park. I noticed two attractive young women across the way who were talking to some guy who had a puppy on a leash. The puppy was doing its excited puppy thing, jumping all over the place, and the guy looked embarrassed talking to the women, as if he were saying "oh, sorry, this dumb dog just runs out and leaps all over the attractive women in the park." After a while, he pulled his dog away and left. A minute later, I saw a different guy walk his dog by the same two women, and let the leash out so his dog does the same thing, and he has the same embarassed conversation. Then, he left... and another guy did the same thing. I mentally crossed out the "dog walking to get chicks" trick from the book... I think it may be just a tad overdone. To their credit, the women seemed genuinely surprised and amused each time some yokel's dog came running up to them. -We slept in too late today and had to use aggresive driving tactics to catch the train to New York. When we were there, we took it nice and easy. We arrived in Penn Station, took the train to the village, took the train back up to the upper east side, walked through central park (on a spectacular day) to the upper west side, took a train back to the village for dinner, then took a train back up to the upper east side for the evening's drinking, then a cab back to Queens. Keep in mind, Jason Bryce and I also lugged our backpacks - with four days gear - through this whole adventure. So, my shoulders and I are no longer on speaking terms. It was like Europe again - without the rash and the limping travel buddy. -We used the rail system extensively, and visited landmarks in both Philly and NYC. Nothing blew up, and we weren't gassed (to our knowledge, anyway). We may have been face scanned - I hear they're using that at the Statue of Liberty. I did get searched twice at the airport on Thursday, but I think that's because I didn't shave. So, we're all safe and sound. -It was Jason Bryce's first time in the city, so Jason, Jason Hammonds, Brandon, Dave and I visited Lucky Cheung's, a bar in the village where the wait staff are extremely attractive women - transvestite women - extremely friendly, outgoing transvestive men dressed as women. I highly recommend this place - it may challenge your sexuality, but you will have a good time in the process. The staff loved Jason Hammonds... a lot. He went to the bathroom and returned a shaken man. He said: "They freaking mauled me... they were lifting up my shirt and I was like, 'man, can I just go to the bathroom'?" Jason Bryce: "Dude, that hot one was into you. "I don't feel good saying that." Maybe you had to be there. But check it out. What else? We ran out of a bar away from a crazy Russian man who trying to set Brandon up with women, I nearly got hit hit by a fleet of cabs jaywalking, Dave almost got run over by a cab when the driver took off in reverse as he was walking behind it, the five of us nearly got into a fight with one angry man on the sidewalk, I hit my chin on a taxicab door getting into it, and I spent about $500 dollars on food and drink. That's the story so far. We'll be in NYC all day tomorrow, and hopefully something interesting will happen. Talk to you all soon... Murph

Hey guys, hate to skip back behind the web development talk - thanks for working on the site, by the way, I appreciate it - but I wanted to chime in on this Citizen Corps/Operation TIPS thing... There's a difference between the Citizen Corps and Operation TIPS. The Citizen Corps is a program intended to increase community infrastructre, especially times of crisis. Ideally, it's supposed to set up a volunteer police force, medical reserve corps, a neighborhood watch program, and a community emergency response teams. None of those ideas suck. Hell, I signed up for the community emergency response teams, which means I get a few days of emergency medical training whenever they get to calling me. After that, should something awful happen in Rochester, I can go do something instead of stand around like a chode. Love that idea. Huge. Great. Wonderful. Operation TIPS, though, is no good. A system by which regular citizens can report "suspicious activity' of other citizens to the government is a really bad idea, especially in this age of anti-terrorist "detainees." It's got a good heart behind it, I think. Or, at least, I'd hope it does. If you read what Tom Ridge has been saying about it, he sure seems surprised that people have reacted to it in this way. In a warm, fuzzy, nice world, it's a system by which truckers and fast food workers and flight school instructors can do something if they see some dude acting like a terrorist. Of course, in a warm, fuzzy, nice world, there aren't any terrorists. So in the cold, slick, mean world that we live in, this is a bang-up way to create a system that can be so abused, and so powerfully abused, as to cause absolute havoc and mayhem nationwide. So, no good. But the citizen corps is not all bad, I don't think. If it's a way to strengthen communities in America, I'd love to try it. Seriously. Because communities could use some strengthening. You know?

Pledge of Annoyance Okay, here's my two cents on the Pledge thang: Here are a few little factoids about the Pledge that aren't getting much mention from the urlLink wingers and urlLink pundits and urlLink politicians who are so outraged by this ruling: The 9th Circuit Court did NOT rule the Pledge of Allegiance unconstitutional. Only the phrase urlLink "under god," which was found to violate the Establishment clause of the First Amendment to the Constitution, based on urlLink established case history . The Pledge of Allegience was written in 1892 by urlLink Francis Bellamy , a Socialist who was forced to resign his position as Baptist Minister because of his 'socialist sermons.' The original Pledge read as follows: ' urlLink I pledge allegiance to my Flag and the Republic for which it stands, one nation, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all. ' Against the wishes of Bellamy, In 1923 and 1924 the National Flag Conference changed the Pledge's words, 'my Flag,' to 'the Flag of the United States of America.' - urlLink They were afraid that immigrants and their children would pledge allegience to the flag of their native country. If we're shaking our heads at this decision, it's because there's some serious cultural schizophrenia happening. I think the 'seperation of church and state' doctrine in the United States is just as vague and confusing as the 'well regulated militia' of the Second Amendment and the definition of 'pornographic' media. What do these things have in common? They're all gray areas that need to be worked out in the community so that everybody can get on with their lives. We need to figure out how much religion people should be exposed to, how many glocks they should have, and whether or not they should be able to get some porn with that. It's a community decision, I think, made up by a consensus (or barring that, a majority) of the people. Problem: the 2000 census reported 281,421,906 people in the United States. "Its a nightmare out there. We live in a cynical and wasteful culture where opinions are made on first impressions and the nice guy finishes sixth. Our culture sabotages our self-image for the sake of profit and prosperity. We are bombarded with marketing and media that tell us that we need to spend to be richer, thinner, or appear wealthier. We are told to submit to a peer-group-directed life twisted towards superficial sentimentality and living in the moment. We are instructed to waste our time and attention on status symbols, interpersonal politics and must-see TV. The reward for our belief in these ideals is a bland-tasting feeling of complacency and a haunting sense of loneliness and alienation. The penalty for failure to conform is eerily similar. Its hard to love life under so much negative reinforcement. Nevertheless, we must love our lives unconditionally. To truly love a partner, we must love everything about them, warts and all. Loving life is no different. We can whine about how unfair our lives are and how we never get what we deserve, but remember this: If we love our worst days as much as the best, if we love crying as much as dancing, and if we love our worst enemies as much as your best friends, we will good lives, miracles will happen in our path, and our goals will be realized Nightmares lose their power over us in the instant that we realize theyre not real."

Appearing in court, the repentant thief said he paid five million rials ($625) to a man who gave him some spells and told him to tie them to his arm to become invisible. "I made a mistake. The Stella awards It's time, once again, to consider the candidates for the annual Stella Awards. The Stella's are named after 81-year-old Stella Liebeck who spilled coffee on herself and successfully sued McDonald's. That case inspired the Stella Awards for the most frivolous successful lawsuits in the United States. The following are this year's candidates: 1. Kathleen Robertson of Austin, Texas, was awarded $780,000 by a jury of her peers after breaking her ankle tripping over a toddler who was running inside a furniture store. The owners of the store were understandably surprised at the verdict, considering the misbehaving little toddler was Ms. Robertson's son. 2. A 19-year-old, Carl Truman of Los Angeles, won $74,000 and medical expenses when his neighbor ran over his hand with a Honda Accord. Mr. Truman apparently didn't notice there was someone at the wheel of the car when he was trying to steal his neighbor's hub caps. 3. Terrence Dickson of Bristol, Pennsylvania, was leaving a house he had just finished robbing by way of the garage. He was not able to get the garage door to go up since the automatic door opener was malfunctioning. He couldn't re-enter the house because the door connecting the house and garage locked when he pulled it shut. The family was on vacation, and Mr. Dickson found himself locked in the garage for eight days. He subsisted on a case of Pepsi he found, and a large bag of dry dog food. He sued the homeowner's insurance claiming the situation caused him undue mental anguish. The jury agreed to the tune of $500,000. 4. Jerry Williams of Little Rock, Arkansas, was awarded $14,500 and medical expenses after being bitten on the buttocks by his next door neighbor's beagle. The beagle was on a chain in its owner's fenced yard. The award was less than sought because the jury felt the dog might have been just a little provoked at the time by Mr. Williams who was shooting it repeatedly with a pellet gun. 5. A Philadelphia restaurant was ordered to pay Amber Carson of Lancaster, Pennsylvania, $113,500 after she slipped on a soft drink and broke her coccyx (tailbone). The beverage was on the floor because Ms. Carson had thrown it at her boyfriend 30 seconds earlier during an argument. 6. Kara Walton of Claymont, Delaware, successfully sued the owner of a night club in a neighboring city when she fell from the bathroom window to the floor and knocked out her two front teeth. This occurred while Ms. Walton was trying to sneak through the window in the ladies room to avoid paying the $3.50 cover charge. She was awarded $12,000 and dental expenses. 7. This year's favorite could easily be Mr. Merv Grazinski of Oklahoma City, Oklahoma. Mr. Grazinski purchased a brand new 32-foot Winnebago motor home. On his first trip home, having driven onto the freeway, he set the cruise control at 70 mph and calmly left the drivers seat to go into the back and make himself a cup of coffee. Not surprisingly, the R.V. left the freeway, crashed and overturned. Mr. Grazinski sued Winnebago for not advising him in the owner's manual that he couldn't actually do this. The jury awarded him $1,750,000 plus a new motor home. The company actually changed their manuals on the basis of this suit, just in case there were any other complete morons buying their recreation vehicles. I wonder why our insurance rates have become so outrageously high?

Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Address delivered in Acceptance of Nobel Peace Prize 10 December 1964 Oslo, Norway Your Majesty, Your Royal Highness, Mr. President, excellencies, ladies and gentlemen: I accept the Nobel Prize for Peace at a moment when twenty-two million Negroes of the United States are engaged in a creative battle to end the long night of racial injustice. I accept this award on behalf of a civil rights movement which is moving with determination and a majestic scorn for risk and danger to establish a reign of freedom and a rule of justice. I am mindful that only yesterday in Birmingham, Alabama, our children, crying out for brotherhood, were answered with fire hoses, snarling dogs, and even death. I am mindful that only yesterday in Philadelphia, Mississippi, young people seeking to secure the right to vote were brutalized and murdered. I am mindful that debilitating and grinding poverty afflicts my people and chains them to the lowest rung of the economic ladder. Therefore, I must ask why this prize is awarded to a movement which is beleaguered and committed to unrelenting struggle, and to a movement which has not yet won the very peace and brotherhood which is the essence of the Nobel Prize. After contemplation, I conclude that this award, which I receive on behalf of that movement, is a profound recognition that nonviolence is the answer to the crucial political and moral questions of our time: the need for man to overcome oppression and violence without resorting to violence and oppression. Civilization and violence are antithetical concepts. Negroes of the United States, following the people of India, have demonstrated that nonviolence is not sterile passivity, but a powerful moral force which makes for social transformation. Sooner or later, all the peoples of the world will have to discover a way to live together in peace, and thereby transform this pending cosmic elegy into a creative psalm of brotherhood. If this is to be achieved, man must evolve for all human conflict a method which rejects revenge, aggression, and retaliation. The foundation of such a method is love. The torturous road which has led from Montgomery, Alabama, to Oslo bears witness to this truth, and this is a road over which millions of Negroes are traveling to find a new sense of dignity. This same road has opened for all Americans a new era of progress and hope. It has led to a new civil rights bill, and it will, I am convinced, be widened and lengthened into a superhighway of justice as Negro and white men in increasing numbers create alliances to overcome their common problems. I accept this award today with an abiding faith in America and an audacious faith in the future of mankind. I refuse to accept despair as the final response to the ambiguities of history. I refuse to accept the idea that the "is-ness" of man's present nature makes him morally incapable of reaching up for the eternal "ought-ness" that forever confronts him. I refuse to accept the idea that man is mere flotsam and jetsam in the river of life, unable to influence the unfolding events which surround him. I refuse to accept the view that mankind is so tragically bound to the starless midnight of racism and war that the bright daybreak of peace and brotherhood can never become a reality. I refuse to accept the cynical notion that nation after nation must spiral down a militaristic stairway into the hell of nuclear annihilation. I believe that unarmed truth and unconditional love will have the final word in reality. This is why right, temporarily defeated, is stronger than evil triumphant. I believe that even amid today's mortar bursts and whining bullets, there is still hope for a brighter tomorrow. I believe that wounded justice, lying prostrate on the blood-flowing streets of our nations, can be lifted from this dust of shame to reign supreme among the children of men. I have the audacity to believe that peoples everywhere can have three meals a day for their bodies, education and culture for their minds, and dignity, equality, and freedom for their spirits. I believe that what self-centered men have torn down, men other-centered can build up. I still believe that one day mankind will bow before the altars of God and be crowned triumphant over war and bloodshed and nonviolent redemptive goodwill proclaimed the rule of the land. And the lion and the lamb shall lie down together, and every man shall sit under his own vine and fig tree, and none shall be afraid. I still believe that we shall overcome. This faith can give us courage to face the uncertainties of the future. It will give our tired feet new strength as we continue our forward stride toward the city of freedom. When our days become dreary with low-hovering clouds and our nights become darker than a thousand midnights, we will know that we are living in the creative turmoil of a genuine civilization struggling to be born. Today I come to Oslo as a trustee, inspired and with renewed dedication to humanity. I accept this prize on behalf of all men who love peace and brotherhood. I say I come as a trustee, for in the depths of my heart I am aware that this prize is much more than an honor to me personally. Every time I take a flight I am always mindful of the many people who make a successful journey possible, the known pilots and the unknown ground crew. You honor the dedicated pilots of our struggle, who have sat at the controls as the freedom movement soared into orbit. You honor, once again, Chief Lutuli of South Africa, whose struggles with and for his people are still met with the most brutal expression of man's inhumanity to man. You honor the ground crew, without whose labor and sacrifice the jet flights to freedom could never have left the earth. Most of these people will never make the headlines, and their names will never appear in Who's Who. Yet, when years have rolled past and when the blazing light of truth is focused on this marvelous age in which we live, men and women will know and children will be taught that we have a finer land, a better people, a more noble civilization because these humble children of God were willing to suffer for righteousness' sake. I think Alfred Nobel would know what I mean when I say I accept this award in the spirit of a curator of some precious heirloom which he holds in trust for its true owners: all those to whom truth is beauty, and beauty, truth, and in whose eyes the beauty of genuine brotherhood and peace is more precious than diamonds or silver or gold. Thank you.

Hey Dan, and Everyone let's start that urlLink Debate blog . Let's start with something a on the lighter side before jumping into war talk, or race talk, something all deep and heavy like that. And let's try and avoid "re-debating" issues that have been/ are being debated to death. For instance no one is really interested in what band has sold out or hasn't. (all this use of the word debate is getting me....tired). And of course, let's try to remember; if you are arguing something that you are uninformed about, then there is no point in debating it. I'm not being facetious, I just mean the whole point of debating (well, what the point SHOULD be) is to take two informed, thought out sides and pit them against each other. Not in any Sophist way, where one side is just trying to win (i.e. make fallacious arguments to give only the appearance of making a point without actually making the point) but in a way that opens up all the perspective and really flushes out the ideas of each point. There is nothing against using the so called, devil's advocate, either to try and flush out ideas and weak spots (though often playing the devil's advocate is done merely to try and win)or to move the argument to each logical step. Remember this is not a competition, and we are trying to debate in the sense that a winning conclusion must be sought. How does anyone/everyone feel about this?

Alamo under siege by termites SAN ANTONIO, Texas (Reuters) -- There is a new battle cry in Texas: Remember the bug spray when you remember the Alamo. The 250-year-old structure, where a small band of Texas volunteers battled to the death against the army of Mexican General Santa Anna in 1836, is under siege again -- this time by termites. "We have some termite damage in the shrine, in one of the windows at the top of the shrine," Alamo Director David Stewart said. The Alamo is mostly made of stone. The termites are attacking wood beams and window frames at the biggest tourist attraction in Texas. The siege of the Alamo lasted thirteen days and ended on March 6, 1836.

Is is an online zine, is it some sort home for journalism majors, what is it will fail? Even though it appears to be a collected group of creative and semi creative people, it's hard to convey that. We should focus on the plausible community aspect, that's what is so damn appealing about itwillfail. A YOUNG mother this week watched helplessly as a baboon snatched and ripped open the skull of her only child and ate his brain. The mother of the dead child, Lettie Goitsimang Tukane (34), told City Press the baboon sank its powerful canines into the skull of her three-month-old son, removed the brain, climbed up a high telephone pole and ate the brain before fleeing into nearby bush. The bizarre and tragic incident occurred at a cattle post in the remote North West village of Madipelesa outside Pampierstad, where Tukane and fiancé Oupa Goeiman live. Tukane said her son Neo was sleeping in a bed in one of the rooms while she was busy washing dishes in another room when she heard his screams. She said when she rushed outside she saw a huge baboon carrying Neo under one of its arms. She tried to scare it off, but the baboon was aggressive and it wanted to attack her too. "It happened so quickly that by the time neighbours came and threw stones and set dogs on it, it had already eaten the brain and scuttled into the bush. I could not believe my eyes when I picked up Neo. "He was still breathing and his skull was opened and he was bleeding profusely," said Tukane. She said Neo was her only child and she hoped he would live because her other children died of natural causes before they reached one year. She said after the funeral they would contact a sangoma to check if the incident was not witchcraft related. The incident, the first of its kind in the area, has shocked people in the North West, especially in the areas of Seoding, Sekhing, Madipelesa and Pampierstad. Petrus Malgas, who tried to help rescue little Neo, told City Press that when he and other neighbours threw stones at the baboon, it climbed up the telephone pole and nonchalantly devoured the child's brain before it fled into the bush. Saomeng Phalatse of Sekhing said the whole episode boiled down to witchcraft, because it was unheard of that a baboon would eat a human being. "Although some people with western beliefs do not believe it, we know for a fact that African chemistry works in these areas. "A few years ago in Taung an inyanga, through her medicines, caused a young man to find himself with his bed and all on the top of his roof. "The incident was even shown on Bop TV. Why should we not believe Tukane was bewitched?" said Gomotseng Badirwang, clutching her two-month-old baby. North West senior environmental officer Richard Gasealahwe said chacma baboons were prevalent in the area, including at the Blue Pool heritage site near Buxton in Taung. Gasealahwe dismissed suggestions of witchcraft, saying the baboon might have thought the child was one of the small goats which Goeiman kept in one of the rooms at the cattle post. "The area is teeming with chacma baboons, which are normally tame. However, when they are very hungry they become aggressive and they eat small goats, starting with the brain. "They also rip off and eat the goats' udders and would also go to residential areas looking for food," Gasealahwe. William Mekgwe of Nature Conservation said the baboon that killed little Neo was an old male, "Rotwe", which had been rejected by the troop. He said they had arranged with their problem animal control unit to trap the baboon because it would go back to the house again, hoping to get small goats.

Suspected Penis Snatcher Beaten to Death Sun Oct 12, 9:46 AM ET BANJUL, Gambia (Reuters) - A 28-year-old man accused of stealing a man's penis through sorcery was beaten to death in the West African country of Gambia, police said. A police spokesman told Reuters that Baba Jallow was killed Thursday by about 10 people in the town of Serekunda, nine miles from the capital Banjul. Reports of penis snatching are not uncommon in West Africa, with purported victims claiming that alleged sorcerers simply touched them to make their genitals shrink or disappear in order to extort cash in the promise of a cure. The police spokesman said many men in Serekunda were now afraid to shake hands, and he urged people not to believe reports of "vanishing" genitals. Belief in sorcery is widespread in West Africa. Seven alleged penis snatchers were beaten to death by angry mobs in Ghana in 1997.

Vote For A Man, Not A Puppet Americans should realize that if they vote for President Bush's re-election, they are really voting for the architects of war - Dick Cheney, Donald Rumsfeld, Paul Wolfowitz and the rest of that cabal of neoconservative ideologues and their corporate backers. I have sadly come to the conclusion that President Bush is merely a front man, an empty suit, who is manipulated by the people in his administration. Bush has the most dangerously simplistic view of the world of any president in my memory. It's no wonder the president avoids press conferences like the plague. Take away his cue cards and he can barely talk. Americans should be embarrassed that an Arab king (Abdullah of Jordan) spoke more fluently and articulately in English than our own president at their joint press conference recently. John Kerry is at least an educated man, well-read, who knows how to think, and who knows that the world is a great deal more complex than Bush's comic-book world of American heroes and foreign evildoers. It's unfortunate that in our poorly educated country, Kerry's very intelligence and refusal to adopt simplistic slogans might doom his presidential election efforts. But Thomas Jefferson said it well, as he did so often, when he observed that "people who expect to be ignorant and free expect what never was and never will be." People who think of themselves as conservatives will really display their stupidity, as I did in the last election, by voting for Bush. Bush is as far from being a conservative as you can get. Well, he fooled me once, but he won't fool me twice. It is not at all conservative to balloon government spending, to vastly increase the power of government, to show contempt for the Constitution and the rule of law, or to tell people that foreign outsourcing of American jobs is good for them, that giant fiscal and trade deficits don't matter, and that people should not know what their government is doing. Bush is the most prone-to-classify, the most secretive president in the 20th century. His administration leans dangerously toward the authoritarian. It's no wonder that the Justice Department has convicted a few Arab-Americans of supporting terrorism. What would you do if you found yourself arrested and a federal prosecutor whispers in your ear that either you can plea-bargain this or the president will designate you an enemy combatant and you'll be held incommunicado for the duration ? This election really is important, not only for domestic reasons, but because Bush's foreign policy has been a dangerous disaster. He's almost restarted the Cold War with Russia and the nuclear arms race. America is not only hated in the Middle East, but it has few friends anywhere in the world thanks to the arrogance and ineptness of the Bush administration. Don't forget, a scientific poll of Europeans found us, Israel, North Korea and Iran as the greatest threats to world peace. I will swallow a lot of petty policy differences with Kerry to get a man in the White House with brains enough not to blow up the world and us with it. Go to Kerry's Web site (http://www.johnkerry.com ) and read some of the magazine profiles on him. You'll find that there is a great deal more to Kerry than the GOP attack dogs would have you believe. Besides, it would be fun to have a president who plays hockey, windsurfs, rides motorcycles, plays the guitar, writes poetry and speaks French. It would be good to have a man in the White House who has killed people face to face (in war). Killing people has a sobering effect on a man and dispels all illusions about war. ---------------------------------------------------------- 2004 by King Features Syndicate, Inc. ----------------------------------------------------------

It's Film Noir month. To help the creative writing process of urlLink Mike Martin and I will be immersing ourselves in the the dark dark world of film noir. On Saturday we watched: The Trial - An Orson Welles exploration of a Kafka story. Very very weird. The accused is never told of the crime he's committed. Lots of shadowy figures and odd story elements. From Hell - Technically not film noir, but alludes to the same mood. This Jack the Ripper story was well done and visited the elements of a madmans mind and leaves you wondering what kind of man could do such horrible deeds. Bladerunner - Again, not technically film noir, but dark and dreary just the same. This Ripley Scott epic of an android hunter was so well done it deserves a digital revisitation of its special effects. Up next: The Stranger, Maltese Falcon and The Crow

I thought she kicked ass, I knew she was a dancer but I didn't know she could also sing. The role of Velma is much more exciting anyway. Also- she had her baby just 6 weeks before she started filming. Queen Latifa as Mama Morton- excellent choice she was perfect. Richard Gere as Billy it was good to see him in something totally different, but I didn't like his voice, to character and comical for the role. The role requires a "leading-man" voice. This, Richard doesn't have. The guy who played Amos- naive, innocent, dumb, and perfect, Mary Sunshine- perfect. Ok, enough about it, just go see it.

I went to see "How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days" with my roommate this past weekend and let me tell you, I have never laughed out loud so hard in a theater. The movie is not only funny, it has eye candy for both sexes - dreamy Texan Matthew McConnaughey and sultry Kate Hudson. I hate the term "chick flicks" and to those who may think this falls into that stereotypical genre, you would be wrong. The film isn't mushy - it's quirky and interesting. As I said, I was actually slapping my knee at some humorous parts. There was a guy in the theater who was laughing so hard at one point he was wheezing! Kate Hudson is great at playing a psycho girlfriend who does everything she can to lose McConnaughey in 10 days as she has to write a column on the subject for the magazine she works for. McConnaughey is trying to win a bet to show he can make a girl fall in love with him in 10 days...which of course explains why he puts up with Hudson's antics of calling his penis "Princess Sophia" among other hilarious things. But again, it's not just a comedy, it's a ROMANTIC comedy and it really is quite adorable and a great date movie. It's one of those films girls will want to buy and watch over and over again with their friends....I know I will at least.
